Content-Type: text/plain;
 charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 
The initial mass fraction of the species at z = 0, will in general not
be the same as 
the specified mass fraction for the flame models because the boundary
condition for species 
is a specified flux, F_k condition as opposed to specified mass
fraction. This flux is equal to the product 
of the specified species mass fraction, Y_k and the specified mass
flux, mdot.  The mass fraction
at the burner or inlet, Y_k[0], will in general be different than one
specified due to diffusive fluxes
to or from the inlet.
 
The equation is discretized as:
F_k = mdot Y_k =  rho[0] * u[0] * Y_k[0] - D_k (Y_k[1] - Y_k[0])/(z[1]
- z[0])
 
 
hope this helps
Dave H.
 


>>> holger.doerr@... 10/21/2006 7:36 AM >>>

Hello,
running the flame1.py burner stabilized flame simulation I recognized
that the concentration of H2O (water) is at z=0 about a third of the
final concentration, a  little depending on the pressure. From my
knowledge of mass balancing the initial concentration must be 0 for
water, and the concentrations at z=0 unequal to zero should be only
those of the educts hydrogen, oxygen and the inertial gas argon. 
I've used the unaltered script flame1.py of cantera-1.6.0, varied only
the pressure within 0.03-1 atm. A similar behaviour is observable for
CK II running premixed H2-O2-Ar flames or C2H2-O2-flames, but this is
no CK II group, but interesting for me (some form of oo-inheritance?-).

Textbooks about combustion (Warnatz et al.) show graphs with initial
water concentrations of zero. 
Is something wrong in my interpretation of the results in flame1.csv? 

Best regards from Germany

Holger    






Yahoo! Groups Links
